DataElement.preferredName: Gastrointestinal Tract Primary Tumor Location Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response used to indicate the anatomic position of the primary gastrointestinal tract tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff._A tumor at the original site of origin._A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.:A tumor at the original site of origin.

Concepts.definition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.
A tumor at the original site of origin.

Property.preferredDefinition: A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

DataElementConcept.origin: ECOG CRF:Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

Concepts.definition: Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.

The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An intermediate part or section; an area that is approximately central within some larger region.: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The anatomical location where the esophagus joins to the stomach.

Concepts.definition: The anatomical location where the esophagus joins to the stomach.
